awd_titl_txt: Auditory Mimics using Membrane-based Biomolecular Arrays
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective of this award is to understand the physical mechanisms that will enable biomolecular materials to mimic the mechanosensitive response properties of animal auditory systems.  This research will build on significant advances in the understanding of hair cell physiology for the purpose of elucidating how these response properties can be mimicked in a biomolecular material.  The approach will be to study the underlying physical mechanisms of mechanotransduction in membrane-based artificial hair cells for the purpose of understanding how the underlying mechanisms control the sensitivity and frequency selectivity of the material system; construct new methods to fabricate arrays of biomolecular materials for use in arrays that contain a large number of artificial hair cell structures, and; conduct systematic experiments on an array of membrane-based artificial hair cells and study both the individual and collective responses of the material system.

If successful, the benefits of this research will include a fuller understanding of the mechanosensitive transduction properties of both natural and artificial hair cells for the long-term purpose of improving methods of treating disorders associated with hearing loss.  Approximately 36 million American adults (about 17 percent) report some degree of hearing loss, and age-related hearing loss affects 18 percent of adults between the ages of 45 and 64 and 47 percent of adults 75 or older. Knowledge will be disseminated through graduate-level research as well as undergraduate educational programs.  The undergraduate programs will benefit from the introduction of a three-year educational project that focuses on physiological modeling of the human auditory system, characterization of artificial systems excited by physiological inputs, and a fundamental understanding of how ion channel-based material systems can mimic the properties of human auditory systems.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of this work is the increase in understanding of biologically-inspired sensing mechanisms in a class of membrane-based artificial hair cells.  Hair cells are utilized in biological systems to sense a variety of stimuli, such as temperature changes, acoustic signals, and vibration.  Our work focused on mimicking the physical geometry and layout of hair cells that are found in the mammalian coclear system.  The important outcomes of this work included an increased understanding of the passive mechanical and vibration response of a novel class of artificial hair cells.  Our embodiment of this concept incorporated a nanoscale lipid membrane as a flexible capacitor whose charge output was correlated with the mechanical vibration of an artificial hair.  We demonstrated that variations in the hair geometry and the properties of the membrane correlated to the changes in sensitivity, and these changes could be modeled with a physical representation of the artificial hair cell.

The second important outcome of this work was demonstrating that arrays of artificial hair cells could be used to measure the intensity of physical stimuli and its location.  A linear array of hair cells was used to localize the origin of a vibrational stimuli as it was moved near the array.  Frequency-based methods were utilized to create a localization strategy that accurately predicted the position of the source relative to the hair location.  Correlation of artificial hair cell output with input intensity was adequate for the case of a single hair, but the ability to measure the intensity of the input was less accurate for the hair cell array due to the hair-to-hair variations in the temporal response.  Time-dependent variations in the artificial hair cell response were also attributed to the inability to measure input intensity with an array.  

The broader impacts of this work were twofold.  First, this project significantly increased the understanding of a very novel biologically-inspired sensing mechanism.  The initial demonstration of this sensing mechanism was performed prior to the award of this project, but the research performed under this award significantly increased the understanding of the physics of the membrane-based sensing and demonstrated that the response could be tailored by judicious design of the surrounding material.  Second, our work demonstrated that an artificial system could mimic the spatial sensing properties of the natural system, even though the fundamental sensing mechanism was quite different.  This demonstrates the validity of the biologically-inspired approach even though the underlying physical mechanism differed from that of the natural system.
